ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: History of archaeologists and what they believed throughout time!
The basis of Archeological thought and processes. How did it develop in different intellectual and cultural realms.
A more thorough understanding of the academic history of archaeology.

This course provided a comprehensive look at various archaeological frameworks and theories from a historical standpoint. Because there was a challenging amount of reading, it also helped me develop better time management and prioritization skills.
This course provided a history of archaeology as a discipline, and then essentially taught students to produce literature reviews for archaeology research.
knowledge about archaeological theories

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lot of lecturing with no visual aids - focus for 2 hour seminar required. Mix of grad/undergrad students which is very nice

Strengths: Trigger (the main reading for the semester) really covers a lot of ground and the class is structured so that we really understand what theoretical concepts like "new archaeology" and "diffusionism" mean. It also emphasizes the importance of theory in archaeology and why we, as scholars, should really put a lot of mental effort into what frameworks we build our scholarship upon. The course was much more "leminar" format in the later half of the course and that felt most conducive to learning rather than a straight seminar format that it kinda began as. Assignments were interesting and well communicated (with presentations of our findings). 

Weaknesses: LOTS of reading each week. Readings can be super dense because of its theoretical focus.
I think this class had a nice conversation component. Maybe less readings would have encouraged me to do more of the readings.
Updates on weekly reading could be announced and done more timely.

We had very good weekly readings along with the texts that I thought aided in understanding the theories from the viewpoint of the time in which the theories were popular. I also liked that for our projects we looked at the history of archaeological theories in other countries rather than solely focusing on the United States development of archaeology. 

There was a considerable amount of reading that was not always possible to keep on top of in detail, but assigning certain readings to various students to lead the discussions helped during the course of the semester.

At times, it was hard to determine the purpose of each class, which basically comprised a long-form lecture from the professor followed by a discussion of readings. On the other hand, the sheer volume of information covered was impressive, and I walked away with a solid understanding of how archaeology developed as a discipline.
overall great course!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It is a major requirement therefore more specific and technical - if you LOVE archaeology, then yes! But I would not take it as an introduction to the field

Yes because I believe that understanding theory and where archaeology came from is extremely important when conducting archaeological work. However, the material is not always the most engaging and it can be easy to become bored or unfocused if you aren't super invested in the material.
If they like archaeology, definitely.
Yes. Knowing academic history of archaeology can help with archaeological research design and interpretation.
Yes. This course is essential if you are studying archaeology. It should probably be a requirement for all archaeology students.
Despite the 400 course level, this course is, in my opinion, a strong introduction to archaeology as a subject. I would recommend this class to anyone interested in the social sciences.
definitely
